sub_topic: Coordination chemistry of lanthanides and actinides
message_1: What is the coordination number and geometry of a complex made up of a trivalent actinide, Am(III), and six ligands with five unpaired electrons in the outermost shell?
message_2:
The coordination number of a complex refers to the number of ligands attached to the central metal ion. In this case, the complex is made up of a trivalent actinide, Am(III), and six ligands. Therefore, the coordination number is 6.

The geometry of a complex depends on the coordination number and the arrangement of the ligands around the central metal ion. For a coordination number of 6, the most common geometry is octahedral. In an octahedral geometry, the six ligands are arranged around the central metal ion with 90-degree angles between them.

So, the coordination number of the complex is 6, and its geometry is octahedral.
